intro: Acacia paula, commonly known as the white wattle, is a shrub native to South Africa. It is characterized by its slender, zigzagging branches and small, yellow flowers that bloom in globular clusters. The plant produces flat, bean-like pods that contain seeds, which are dispersed by wind. Acacia paula thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or sandy habitats. It is valued for its ornamental appeal and ability to withstand dry conditions.

distribution_native_art_desc: Acacia paula is primarily native to Western Australia. It is found in the southern and western regions of the state, particularly in the areas of the Fitzgerald River National Park and the Stirling Range. This species thrives in sandy soils and is commonly found in coastal and inland shrublands. It is well adapted to the dry and warm climate of its native habitat. Acacia paula plays an important ecological role in the local environment by providing shelter and food for native wildlife.

It has since spread beyond cultivated areas and is now considered a weed in several regions, particularly in Queensland and New South Wales.
